Award.AwardTitle: A taxon-rich phylogeny of Galliformes: using multiple loci to resolve conflicts among previous studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will use multiple genes to produce a well-resolved evolutionary tree for the avian order Galliformes, which includes the two most economically important birds (the chicken and turkey), some of the most spectacular and recognizable birds (such as peafowl and pheasants), and some of the most important avian model systems (e.g., the chicken and Japanese quail). This order also includes some of the most commonly hunted birds, many of which have been the focus of management studies. Hunting, combined with other factors such as habitat loss, has led to population declines, and many of these species are now of conservation concern. Evolutionary relationships in this group are poorly resolved, which has limited the ability to put the extensive information about galliform species into a comparative framework and hindered decisions regarding conservation priorities. In addition to producing a well-resolved phylogeny of the Galliformes, the collection of large numbers of loci for many species will allow us to explore several other issues, including several rapid radiations at different evolutionary depths and the impact of factors that can cause discordance between individual genes and the species history.

The data generated from this project will also be used to develop classroom exercises for undergraduate courses in genetics and evolution, allowing large numbers of students to conduct research in the classroom. This will facilitate our efforts to improve science pedagogy and allow students to contribute to cutting-edge evolutionary research. The data from this study will be made broadly available through public databases and our own websites for other researchers to use.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The avian order Galliformes contains many of the best-known bird species, including the chicken, turkey, quails, grouse, as well as popular zoo birds such as peafowl and pheasants. Many galliforms are endangered in the wild and those species have been the subjects of conservation efforts. Other galliforms, like the quail, pheasants, and wild turkey, represent important game species that must be properly managed for hunters. Given their importance it seems reasonable to postulate that expanding our knowledge of galliform biology will prove to be important.

Several species within this group have been very well studied, in part due to their economic importance. Thus, we know more about the physiology, development, and genetics of galliform birds than we do for any other group of birds. However, the ways that the various well-studied galliform species are related to each other (and to other galliform species) has been controversial and poorly resolved. Our study collected data from thousands of regions spread across the genome to resolve evolutionary relationships among all of the galliform model systems, as well as most other galliform species, to overcome this problem. Due to this project, we now have a robust, well-resolved and stable set of relationships that can inform researchers that work in other areas of galliform biology and allow them to place their results into an evolutionary framework.

In addition to resolving relationships among species, we also used the data we have collected to explore the best approaches for analyzing the type of large datasets that we collected. Many other researchers are now collecting similar datasets so our results have provided specific guidelines to other researchers conducting similar analyses. 

The project also supported two postdoctoral researchers (one of whom now has a permanent position), each of who obtained several first-authored papers and were co-authors on other papers as well. Ten undergraduates contributed to the project, gaining valuable research experience. Several of these students wrote honors theses based on work done on this project, and so far two students have published their work in international peer-reviewed journals (and others are still working toward that goal). These undergraduates were primarily women (seven of ten), and three were from historically underrepresented groups.

In addition to our reserach goals, we also achieved educational goals. We have developed an authentic research class for undergraduates based on the work some of the undergraduates have done for this project. This class assembles complete mitochondrial genomes from next-generation sequencing data. Students learn about doing research, about sequencing and genomic technologies, genetics (through understanding and ensuring assemblies are correct), as well as evolution and phylogenetic estimation. We had not anticipated this outcome on the project, but through working with students in our lab we realized we could implement this in a classroom setting, giving a greater number of students the opportunity to gain valuable research experience. The goal of the class is to produce a phylogeny based upon the data that can be submitted to peer-reviewed journals. 

Finally, we have made the data we collected through this project available in public databases. We have submitted all of our data to Genbank as we have published it. Alignments and phylogenies have been deposited in Dryad, Figshare, or made available on journal websites (as supplementary materials). In addition, we have written custom scripts for some analyses and we have also made them available through the same sources.
